# Improvement Suggestions

*Generated by LLM (llama3-gradient:latest) on 2025-12-05*
*Output: 21,958 chars (3,776 words) in 145.9s*

---

## Summary

The manuscript is well-structured and provides a clear overview of the main improvements that are required to bring it up to publication standard. The most critical issues for immediate attention are addressed in the first section, with the rest providing additional recommendations. Overall, the content is good but requires some improvement to make it more robust.

## High Priority Improvements

### WHAT: The manuscript does not provide a clear summary of its main points at the beginning.
#### WHY: A summary would be helpful for readers who are interested in the overall results and do not want to read the entire paper. It is also important for reviewers to quickly see what the authors have done, so they can focus on specific aspects that require close attention.

#### HOW: The authors should provide a clear summary of their main points at the beginning of the manuscript, ideally after the abstract but before any section headers.

### WHAT: There are no references in the text.

#### WHY: References are required for most journals. They help readers verify the information and also provide further reading if they want to learn more about a topic.

#### HOW: The authors should add references at the end of the manuscript, following the format of their chosen citation style.

### WHAT: There is no discussion of the limitations of the methods used in the paper.

#### WHY: A discussion of the limitations of the method would be important for readers who want to know more about the topic. It also provides an opportunity for the authors to acknowledge any potential biases or issues with the data that they have not addressed, and to suggest further work.

#### HOW: The authors should discuss their methods in the discussion section at the end of the paper. They can also provide references to the relevant literature if needed.

### WHAT: There is no discussion of the implications of the results.

#### WHY: A discussion of the implications of the results would be important for readers who want to know more about the topic. It also provides an opportunity for the authors to suggest further work that could be done in this area, and to acknowledge any potential biases or issues with the data that they have not addressed, and to suggest further work.

#### HOW: The authors should discuss their results in the discussion section at the end of the paper. They can also provide references to the relevant literature if needed.

### WHAT: The authors do not present a clear comparison of their methods and other related research.

#### WHY: A comparison with other research would be important for readers who want to know more about the topic. It is also an opportunity for the authors to acknowledge any potential biases or issues with the data that they have not addressed, and to suggest further work. The authors could compare the results of their methods with those obtained by others.

#### HOW: The authors should provide a comparison of their methods and other related research in the discussion section at the end of the paper. They can also provide references to the relevant literature if needed.

### WHAT: There is no discussion of the potential biases or issues that could be present in the data.

#### WHY: A discussion of the potential biases or issues with the data would be important for readers who want to know more about the topic.
